title: AI likely to displace jobs, says Bank of England governor
summary:
AI likely to displace jobs, says Bank of England governorHowever, he warned that there was an issue with younger, inexperienced professionals finding it difficult to secure entry-level roles due to AI.
Andrew Bailey said the UK needed to have the "training, education, [and] skills in place" so workers could shift into jobs that use AI.
The widespread adoption of artificial intelligence (AI) is likely to displace people from jobs in a similar way seen during the Industrial Revolution, the governor of the Bank of England has said.
Entry-level professional jobs are thought to be most impacted by AI, particularly in sectors such as law, accountancy and administration.
Mr Bailey said AI was the "most likely source of the next leg up" for UK economic growth.

title: Putin's annual Q&A with Russians is back. 2 issues are front and center.
summary:
Russian President Vladimir Putin is set to field questions from his countrymen about the war in Ukraine and the state of the economy.
Russian President Vladimir Putin is set to field questions from his countrymen about the war in Ukraine and the state of the economy.
Gavriil Grigorov/Poll/AFP/Getty ImagesRussian President Vladimir Putin is set to field questions from his countrymen about the war in Ukraine and the state of the economy.
Russian President Vladimir Putin is preparing for his annual televised Q&A session, and a new poll shows Russians remain focused on two issues: the war and the economy.
These two concerns have topped Levada's polls ahead of Putin's annual Q&A for three years.

title: Russia’s economy is struggling. But that won’t bring Putin to the negotiating table for years
summary:
But the gathering economic storm is unlikely to bring President Vladimir Putin to the negotiation table anytime soon to end the war in Ukraine.
“Russian soldiers today are paid more than any Russian soldier in the history of Russian soldiers,” RUSI’s Connolly said.
Some of Russia’s more deprived areas have experienced an uplift during the war, in part because of huge pay checks going to Russian soldiers and their families.
“They (Russian oil producers) are rerouting oil exports through smaller Russian companies… That is all costing a lot of money,” she said.
If that is combined with stronger sanctions enforcement and increased pressure on India and China to stop buying Russian oil, the Kremlin could eventually change its calculus, she argued.

title: Can Trump convince voters on the US economy?
summary:
The timing of the president’s speech comes after polling suggests the Republican Party is losing support over the direction of the economy.
Will Republicans be able to convince voters that they should still be trusted on the economy ahead of next year’s midterms?

title: There's One Thing Trump Could Do To Turbocharge The Global Economy And Crush Inflation
summary:
There's no indication that tariffs will suddenly be removed, but the paper highlighted the extreme impact they've had on the global economy.
President Donald Trump could invigorate the global economy and stamp out inflation quickly.
That's a boost of 0.5 percentage points per year, all while reducing inflation for U.S. consumers.
"One year after "liberation day," the U.S. administration starts lowering U.S. tariffs back to the levels at end-2024."
Liberation from "Liberation Day" would not only reinvigorate global trade, but would help household budgets for U.S. consumers.

title: Inflation drops to lowest level in months, defying expectations of uptick
summary:
People shop at a grocery store in Brooklyn on December 12, 2025 in New York City.
Inflation dropped in November, ending a monthslong acceleration of price increases and offering relief for households strained by cost hikes, government data on Thursday showed.
The report offered the first look at price increases in nearly two months, after the 43-day government shutdown impaired data collection.
The White House touted the inflation report as a sign of progress in in its effort to slow price increases.
"There's no risk-free path for policy as we navigate this tension between our employment and inflation goals," Powell added.

title: Israel approves 19 new settlements in occupied West Bank
summary:
Israel approves 19 new settlements in occupied West BankSaudi Arabia condemned the move.
Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank are considered illegal under international law.
Israel's security cabinet has approved the recognition of 19 new settlements in the occupied West Bank as the government continues its settlement expansion push.
In May, Israel approved 22 new settlements in the occupied West Bank - the biggest expansion in decades.
It has also raised concerns about the possible annexing of the occupied West Bank.

title: Calculated Risk: Ten Economic Questions for 2026
summary:
1) Economic growth: Economic growth was probably close to 2% Q4-over-Q4 in 2025.
3) Unemployment Rate: The unemployment rate was at 4.6% in November, up from 4.2% in November 2024.
Will the core inflation rate decrease further in 2026, and what will the YoY core inflation rate be in December 2026?
Currently the FOMC is projecting the unemployment rate will decrease to the 4.3% to 4.4% range in Q4 2026.
Long term, the BLS is projecting the overall participation rate will decline to 61.1% by 2034 due to demographics.

title: Trump revisits a North Carolina town, now the focus of a newly redrawn congressional district
summary:
Trump recalled his time in real estate when he used to visit North Carolina to purchase furniture for hotels and lobbies.
The Trump administration recently placed tariffs on imported home furnishings, which Trump told the crowd will help revive North Carolina's furniture industry.
Other recent polls have shown that Trump is losing popularity with voters in North Carolina, a state he's won in three consecutive presidential elections.
North Carolina will be home to one of the country's most-anticipated U.S. Senate races next year.
North Carolina voters have also shown a willingness in recent elections to split their tickets.

title: Trump announces 'warrior dividend' for troops as he defends economic record
summary:
Trump announces 'warrior dividend' for troops as he defends economic record4 days ago Share Save Bernd Debusmann Jr , Washington and Anthony Zurcher , North America correspondent Share SaveWatch: Trump says service members will receive $1,776 "warrior dividend"US President Donald Trump has announced a "warrior dividend" payment to US service members, in a speech in which he also defended his track record on the economy after 11 months back in office.
In a televised address to the nation on Wednesday, Trump said cheques for $1,776 (£1,329) for 1.45 million US service members were already on the way" and should arrive before Christmas.
In the combative address, Trump also touted his achievements on immigration while railing against opposition Democrats.
Schumer added: "People are feeling squeezed harder and harder every day and tonight Donald Trump took a victory lap."
In the brief, 18-minute address, Trump said the "warrior dividend", which totals $2.57bn (£1.9bn), would be distributed "in honour of our nation's founding in 1776".

title: Average US long-term mortgage rate edges lower, remaining near its low for the year
summary:
The average rate on a 30-year U.S. mortgage edged lower this week, staying relatively close to its low for the year.
The decline brings the average long-term mortgage rate to 6.21% from 6.22% last week, mortgage buyer Freddie Mac said Thursday.
Mortgage rates began easing in July in anticipation of a series of Fed rate cuts, which began in September and continued this month.
That can help lower yields on long-term U.S. Treasurys, which can result in lower mortgage rates.
Even so, Fed rate cuts don’t always translate into lower mortgage rates.

title: Long lines at the food pantry: Inflation tests Trump’s base in Michigan
summary:
CAPAC, Michigan, Dec 21 (Reuters) - On a recent snowy morning in a Trump-loving part of rural Michigan, three dozen cars idled outside a firehouse-turned-food pantry.
Ludwig said she had expected Trump to have made greater ​progress on inflation nearly a year into his presidency.
But now, persistent inflation is testing that pledge — and the patience of voters who helped put him in office.
A dozen said they would still vote Republican, and three said they were unsure or did not share their voting plans.
Advertisement AdvertisementAdvertisement AdvertisementHe predicted Trump's tariffs would bring back high-paying manufacturing jobs and boost wages above the rate of inflation.

title: ‘This is a wacky number’: economists cry foul as new government data assumes zero housing inflation in surprising November drop
summary:
But for many economists, the numbers immediately raised red flags, especially on housing, the single largest component of inflation.
When housing is that large a component, that really matters.”The culprit, several economists say, is the extended government shutdown, which disrupted the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ ability to collect price data throughout October and into November.
Instead, it relied on statistical assumptions—often “carrying forward” previous prices—that effectively treated some categories as if inflation had stopped altogether.
“This was one flawed CPI report,” he wrote.
Normally, market watchers would expect a meaningful drop in inflation would spark a sharp rally in stocks—or, in these days of bad data being good and good data being bad—a selloff as markets reprice interest-rate expectations.

title: Ukraine loan: Europe salvages credibility with $105 billion deal, reserves right to use Russian assets to fund it
summary:
Instead, EU leaders opted to borrow the money from investors for a loan to Ukraine while reserving the right to use the Russian assets in the future.
“It is important that Russian assets remain immobilized and that Ukraine has received a financial security guarantee for the coming years.
Sofiia Gatilova/ReutersThe idea of using the frozen assets of Russia’s central bank wasn’t a new one.
Until now, the EU has been using the interest from the Russian assets, which are mostly bonds, to finance some of its support for Kyiv.
The assets frozen in Europe account for most of Moscow’s immobilized assets globally.

title: Bitcoin price to hit $200,000 by March as Fed ‘thinly disguises’ new money printing tool, says Arthur Hayes
summary:
Arthur Hayes predicts Bitcoin will hit $200,000 by March 2026 when markets recognise that the Fed is printing money.
“As the market equates RMP to QE, Bitcoin will quickly retake $124,000 and punch quickly towards $200,000,” Hayes wrote.
Once they realise the Fed has “thinly disguised” and is actually printing massive amounts of new money, Bitcoin will surge to $200,000 by March, Hayes said.
Unlike the Fed’s infamous money printing programme from 2008 to 2020 that had end dates and limits, this new programme can run forever with no ceiling.
The peak comes in March, which is when expectations for Fed money printing hit their highest, Hayes said.

title: Consumer sentiment has seen a 'substantial decline' this year
summary:
The final read on December consumer sentiment from the University of Michigan actually came in lower than the prior read and below where Wall Street had forecast those numbers.
At both the preliminary read and the final read that we released today, we saw very, very modest improvements from November that weren't actually outside the margin of error.

Um, even though their inflation expectations have come down, um, for for four straight months now, I think for for the short run inflation expectations, um, we're still, their inflation expectations still are higher than they were in 2024.

title: Next-generation nuclear reactors could get a boost from the National Defense Authorization Act
summary:
President Trump signed the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 2026 Thursday with measures that further the bipartisan push for next-generation nuclear power plants.
The Trump administration has embraced the technology as a new energy source for data centers demanding greater amounts of electricity for AI.
Many Democrats, meanwhile, have championed smaller and ostensibly cheaper and easier-to-build nuclear reactors as a carbon pollution-free energy source that can help fight climate change.
The International Nuclear Energy Act establishes working groups and boosts funding and interagency cooperation on the development and export of US nuclear technologies.
The bill also directs the Department of Defense to create an executive agent role “for installation and operational nuclear energy.”

title: Calculated Risk: Review: Ten Economic Questions for 2025
summary:

The analysis for the housing related questions were posted in the newsletter, and the other questions on this blog.
Mortgage rates will remain well above the pandemic lows, and new listings will likely be depressed again in 2025 compared to pre-pandemic levels.
10) Question #10 for 2025: Will inventory increase further in 2025?
This is down from the post pandemic peak of 62.8%.
